references: We then consider OF-MRTP by setting α={0.25,0.5}𝛼0.250.5\alpha=\left\{0.25,0.5\right\}, at​h={5,10}subscript𝑎𝑡ℎ510a_{th}=\left\{5,10\right\}, fm​a​x={0.3,0.4}subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥0.30.4f_{max}=\left\{0.3,0.4\right\}, and γm​i​n=1subscript𝛾𝑚𝑖𝑛1\gamma_{min}=1. The test accuracy and average per round latency results are presented in Table I. We note that, if a round-robin scheduler is employed with participation ratio 20%percent2020\%, then the maximum age will be at,k=5subscript𝑎𝑡𝑘5a_{t,k}=5, and similarly, the maximum participation frequency will be fk,t=0.2subscript𝑓𝑘𝑡0.2f_{k,t}=0.2. Therefore, to setup the parameter values at​hsubscript𝑎𝑡ℎa_{th} and fm​a​xsubscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥f_{max}, we consider these values as our reference points. One can easily observe from Table I that with OF-MRTP the average latency as well as the variation on the latency significantly drops, since client k𝑘k is scheduled only if Rkul​(n)>R¯kul​(n)superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘ul𝑛superscriptsubscript¯𝑅𝑘ul𝑛R_{k}^{\text{ul}}(n)>\bar{R}_{k}^{\text{ul}}(n). Besides, thanks to the control on the participation frequency of the clients, we also observe a significant improvement in the test accuracy. We also want to remark that when at​h=10subscript𝑎𝑡ℎ10a_{th}=10, we observe similar test accuracy and latency results for other parameters. The reason is that since MRTP is used for client scheduling when 𝒞^i​d​l​e​(t)=∅superscript^𝒞𝑖𝑑𝑙𝑒𝑡\hat{\mathcal{C}}^{idle}(t)=\emptyset, at the same time larger at​hsubscript𝑎𝑡ℎa_{th} increases the probability of 𝒞^i​d​l​e​(t)superscript^𝒞𝑖𝑑𝑙𝑒𝑡\hat{\mathcal{C}}^{idle}(t) being empty, thus more clients are scheduled according to MRTP. This observation is also backed by the simulation results with at​h=5subscript𝑎𝑡ℎ5a_{th}=5, where the impact of the parameter α𝛼\alpha is more visible. Not surprisingly the minimum latency is achieved when more clients are scheduled according to MRTP and we allow larger participation frequencies. Interestingly, in this case, where α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5 and fm​a​x=0.4subscript𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥0.4f_{max}=0.4, we do not observe a compromise on the test accuracy.

For comparison, we consider MRTP and random scheduling as benchmark. Note that these are the optimal strategies, respectively, from the latency and fairness perspectives. In Fig. 1, we compare the convergence behaviour of the OF-MRTP, A-MRTP and MRTP schemes. As one would expect, the test accuracy increases faster with MRTP; however, due to the non-iid distribution of the data it converges to a sub-optimal model and eventually diverges111The test accuracy is plotted until the divergence point.. While A-MRTP eventually reaches an accuray level above MRTP (see Table II), it introduces significant latency due to scheduling the clients with poor channel conditions to reduce their age. The convergence behaviour of random scheduling is not included in the figure since the average per-round latency is very high, instead, we compare OF-MRTP and random scheduling based on the final test accuracy results which is averaged over 10 trails. We observe that the average final test accuracy with random scheduling is 83.92±0.37plus-or-minus83.920.3783.92\pm 0.37. In comparison with the test accuracy results in Table I, we can conclude that OF-MRTP does not compromise the accuracy while significantly reducing the latency.

references: We first consider the A-MRTP scheme. For the experiments, we consider α={0.7,0.9}𝛼0.70.9\alpha=\{0.7,0.9\}. The average per round latency and test accuracy results are presented in Table II. As predicted, we observe that by decreasing α𝛼\alpha; that is, scheduling more clients according to the age-metric, both the test accuracy and the average latency increase.

For comparison, we consider MRTP and random scheduling as benchmark. Note that these are the optimal strategies, respectively, from the latency and fairness perspectives. In Fig. 1, we compare the convergence behaviour of the OF-MRTP, A-MRTP and MRTP schemes. As one would expect, the test accuracy increases faster with MRTP; however, due to the non-iid distribution of the data it converges to a sub-optimal model and eventually diverges111The test accuracy is plotted until the divergence point.. While A-MRTP eventually reaches an accuray level above MRTP (see Table II), it introduces significant latency due to scheduling the clients with poor channel conditions to reduce their age. The convergence behaviour of random scheduling is not included in the figure since the average per-round latency is very high, instead, we compare OF-MRTP and random scheduling based on the final test accuracy results which is averaged over 10 trails. We observe that the average final test accuracy with random scheduling is 83.92±0.37plus-or-minus83.920.3783.92\pm 0.37. In comparison with the test accuracy results in Table I, we can conclude that OF-MRTP does not compromise the accuracy while significantly reducing the latency.
